problem: Let $f(x)=x+1$ and $g(x)=2x$.  Also denote the inverses to these functions as $f^{-1}$ and $g^{-1}$.  Compute \[f(g^{-1}(f^{-1}(f^{-1}(g(f(5)))))).\]
solution:
Since $f$ is the function that adds one, $f^{-1}$ is the function that subtracts one.  Since $g$ is the function that doubles, $g^{-1}$ is the function that halves.  This lets us compute from inside out:

\begin{align*}
&f(g^{-1}(f^{-1}(f^{-1}(g(f(5))))))\\
&=f(g^{-1}(f^{-1}(f^{-1}(g(6)))))&\text{added 1}\\
&=f(g^{-1}(f^{-1}(f^{-1}(12))))&\text{doubled}\\
&=f(g^{-1}(f^{-1}(11)))&\text{subtracted 1}\\
&=f(g^{-1}(10))&\text{subtracted 1}\\
&=f(5)&\text{half}\\
&=\boxed{6}&\text{added 1}.
\end{align*}
